newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission will maintain beef export refund rates.
newsitem.headline: Commission will maintain beef export refund rates.

text.p: The European Commission has lifted a suspension on applications for beef export licences introduced last week, and will not cut refund rates as expected, a Commission official said on Thursday.
"Licences were suspended some days ago because of the very high-level of applications, but a decision has been taken not to cut the refund rates," the official said.
The Commission is relying on what it calls "a measure of discipline among traders" not to raise applications for licences above acceptable levels before next Tuesday when they close.
"If the level of applications is again too high then they will have to be suspended again," the official said.
Trade sources told Reuters that they were expecting refund rates to be cut at the next beef management committee meeting on January 17.
"This is very good news for beef farmers at a time when beef exports are again coming under pressure because of BSE (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy)," one farmers' organisation official said.

The Egyptian government this week announced a six month ban on imports of live beef cattle from Ireland, Portugal, France and Switzerland because of fears that they could be infected with mad cow disease.
The European Commission said that the ban was unjustified and it would ask Egypt to lift it. REUTER
